newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka's beaches under threat of erosion.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka's beaches under threat of erosion.

text.p: Sri Lanka's coastline is losing up to 300,000 square metres (yards) annually to erosion, most critically along a 1,680 km (1,050 miles) tourist strip in the southwest, a government official said on Wednesday.
"Between 150,000 and 300,000 square metres, predominantly in the southwest sector, is being lost annually," Nissanka Perera, director of the Coast Conservation Department, told Reuters.
"This is due to natural erosion and man-made factors."
Fifty-five percent of the beaches south of the capital Colombo are severely threatened by erosion, he said.
This is caused largely by the reef being depleted through coral mining, with as many as 18,000 tonnes excavated annually, Perera said.
Coral, used locally in construction, acts as a natural barrier against erosion and is vital to the support of marine-life.
"Coral reef is primarily required for the existence of the coastal eco-system," Perera said.

"Reefs also provide natural barriers against erosion, especially during the monsoon seasons," he added. "With the removal of reef, that protection is removed and so waves break a lot closer to the shore."
According to the conservationist, the long-term solution to the problem was to import sand to affected areas of coastline.

But since sand-mining of riverbeds was quickly reaching saturation -- at such a rate that river-beds were already dropping below sea-levels -- the only sound option was to pump sand in from beyond the reefs.
"We will have to supplement the sand on the beaches by pumping more in from off-shore areas, except that is costly," Perera said.

His department's 1997 budget was limited to 40 million rupees ($690,000), he said, adding that a 1987 Danish-funded initiative to pump sand into the Negombo area, north of Colombo, cost 155 million rupees. ($1 = 58 rupees)
